Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Rationally Designed Conjugated Polymers Based on Benzobisazoles
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY. Conjugated polymers are of tremendous scientific and technological importance for use in applications such as photovoltaics cells, light-emitting diodes and thin-film transistors. The ability to modify the electronic properties of conjugated polymers through chemical synthesis allows for the optimizaton of their properties for specific applications. However, iin spite of the large number of synthetically accessible conjugated polymers, the values remains an important goal in the field. Among existing conjugated polymers, poly (benzobisazoles) are well suited for use in organic semi-conducting applications because they combine photoluminescence and efficient electron transport with excellent thermal stability. Historically, fully conjugated poly (benzobisazoles) are insoluble in aprotic solvents, limiting their use. Recently, the Jeffries-EL group has demonstrated that soluble poly (benzobisazoles) can be synthesized via an approach that allows for easy variation of the side chains. This CAREER award will support efforts to (1) design and synthesize novel soluble poly (arylene benzobisazole) polymers, (ii) investigate the influence of polymer structure on the optical, electronic and physical properties of these materials, and (iii) foster interest in polymer science through an outreach effort targeting underrepresented students in the 8th - 12th grade. this research will elucidate the relationship between polymer structures and electronic properties providing a rational basis for synthesizing conductive polymers with optimized properties for organic electronics.

NON-TECHNIAL SUMMARY. Conjugated polymers are being explored both academically and commercially for use in semi-conducting applications. The motivation behind their use is the ability to make large area films using solution-processing techniques such as inkjet printing, which translates into a significant reduction in the cost of device manufacture. This CAREER award will (i) support research intended to increase basic knowledge for designing conjugated polymers with optimized properties for use as "plastic" electronics (ii) provide interdisciplinary research experiences for both undergraduate and graduate students, and (iii) foster interest in polymer science through a creative outreach effort targeting underrepresented students in the 8th - 12th grade.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to synthesize new carbon-based electronic materials with properties that could be altered to match the requirements of specific applications. Some of the potential and actual uses of these materials include: solar cells, light emitting diodes, sensors, and transistors. The focus of this work was a group of molecules known as the benzobisazoles. These molecules possess several excellent properties but have not been widely studied because previous methods of preparation required harsh conditions. Our group pioneered the synthesis of these molecules in high yields and under mild conditions. We were then able to prepare polymers by combining these molecules with several others facilitating the optimization of the materials properties. During this project we have developed several new organic electronic materials, of particular interest are our blue-light emitting polymers. In general, such materials have the potential to be used in display technology and in solid-state lighting. Both of which have real implications on energy consumption. We have also developed several polymers for use in solar cells. Although, the performance of these materials is currently below the state-of-the art in the field, the overall low-cost of the starting materials is beneficial for large-scale production. Lastly, the scientific insight gained during this project will enable the development of new and improved materials, in our group and others in the future.

 

In addition to our scientific work we have made significant contributions to human resource development. Seven graduate students have been partially supported by this grant including two women and one male member of an underrepresented minority (URM) group. Five of these students have completed their doctorate degrees and one has finished a masters. Eighteen undergraduates have also worked on this project including three students supported during the summer, three women and one URM. There was also a substantial outreach effort targeting underrepresented students in the 8th -12th grade. Three URM high school students have participated via support from the American Chemical Society’s (ACS) project SEED and the Ames High School Intern Program. In addition to the research opportunities offered in her lab, the PI also developed an outreach program called the Chemistry Ambassadors program in which eight current upper class ISU students participated in a peer-led mentoring activity. The activities for this program included demonstrations to expose middle school and high school students to the chemical sciences and professional development to strengthen their presentation and communication skills. In addition to performing demonstrations, the Chemistry Embassadors shared their stories of how they became successful college students. The populations impacted by this activity included two at risk groups: URM students and potential first generation college students. The presentations were made to student groups, impacting 300 URM students and an additional 2,800 middle and high school students during the past five years.

 

In sum, the research funded by this grant has enabled the development of new organic electronic materials that can be used in several applications. The fundamental insights obtained will also lead to other new materials. Lastly, it also provided an opportunity to train the next generation of scientists, and provide them with the technical skills obtained by working in an interdisciplinary environment that will be beneficial in their future pursuits.
